narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Ethics, Global Health
I learned about numerous ethical perspectives on a number of global health dilemmas. I also generally learned a lot about current issues in global health.

By taking this course, you learn how to approach ethical dilemmas through different philosophical frameworks. You learn about the history of bioethics. It also teaches you the tensions between populations (ie: physicians, researchers, the general public, developed nations, developing nations).
I developed an understanding of the ethical frameworks that should be used to analyze global health issues.
How to use ethical frameworks to analyze healthcare and policy issues.

We learned various topics of global health ethical dilemmas ranging from surveillance to artificial intelligence. As a class, we had successful and thoughtful discussions and were able to learn perspectives from one another.

In this class, I learned more about ethical frameworks in addition to many of the ethical dilemmas in global health work. The course challenged my understanding of universal good and encouraged me to think more critically about the different programs set in place for global health.
I improved my writing, acquired a much higher understanding of ethical issues in global health, and developed a framework and process for confronting and analyzing ethical issues more broadly.
I learned a lot about writing academic papers, ethical frameworks and analysis, and about specific interesting case studies.

I gained important skills on analyzing topics in public/global health, such as global research, migration, child/maternity health, etc., through ethical principles and frameworks. The format of the class was discussion-based which allowed for rich discussions and insights to be shared among students of different educational backgrounds, strengthening our critical thinking skills of the topics presented. Overall, the course has been helpful in helping me view public health from a different lens to consider justice, equity, and other principles

Learned about a variety of ethical frameworks, including consequentialism, deontology, virtue ethics, humanism, feminist ethics-of-care and more. I learned how to apply these frameworks to perform an ethical analysis on a dilemma, with specific practice in the context of health. Analyzed a variety of health-related ethical dilemmas.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Cara is the best strength. She is truly a phenomenal teacher and allows students to guide the discussion and interjects to add specific points and introduce thought-provoking questions that make for interesting discussions.
I thought this class was incredibly engaging. The conversations we had were well-guided and every student felt comfortable to share their insights, which made for a really active class environment.

A strength of this class is the discussion style of the seminars where we can really delve deep into the topic and the readings and we get to hear outside perspectives. However, a weakness of this class is the way break out rooms were conducted. Sometimes when we came back into the big class, the discussions of the break-out rooms will be repetitive.
Overall the class was incredibly well put together. The readings were thoughtfully picked and there were rich discussions in class.
Very interesting, very broad and very well organized. The readings were well chosen too.
The topics chosen were dwelled well in-depth and gave a holistic viewpoint of ethics in global health. The course itself is already superb and having more group activities would make it even better.

I really loved this course! I think that having weekly student leaders send out the reading guide with questions was a very effective way to structure the class and helped me better prepare for discussion. I do think that this class would benefit from a wider variety of types of assignments because I found myself slipping into similar arguments for multiple papers.

Strengths: Professor Fallon is amazing, really fun discussions, clear feedback on written assignments. 
Weakness: I am unsure what my grade will be because we did not receive clear feedback on our participation or presentation grades throughout the semester. Maybe these grades could be posted next time?
I think the course was well organized and moderated. I think it could have been helpful to have more assignments besides just the papers.

Strengths: Having the course be discussion-based, instead, of lecture-based, was very helpful in exploring the concepts presented in weekly readings. Instead of Professor Fallon simply presenting her ideas, she allowed each of us to share our thoughts and questions. In this way, our discussions were not linear but covered many concepts to enrich our knowledge.
Weaknesses: It would be nice to still have some visual resources to follow along as we discuss. But otherwise, I thought this course was wonderful!

Strengths: I liked that it was a discussion course and I enjoyed hearing the perspectives of other people in the class. Content and readings were generally interesting. Class was well-structured and expectations were clear. Prof. Fallon was sensitive to the challenges of hosting a long-format discussion course on Zoom and gave us a break during the class as well as a varying check-in question for attendance. I liked the weekly student presentations on readings, though sometimes they substantially cut into discussion time if they were very long.

Weaknesses: Zoom whiteboards and small groups ended up with repeated information/pacing issues. I think there could be an effort to source more readings from voices that aren't generally promoted (ex: we looked at the ethics of "service learning trips" for medical students, often to low-resource areas, but we didn't get any accounts from those on the receiving end).

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Zoom seminars swirled well, including techniques used such as the whiteboard.
I think this class was well-suited for a virtual format. The breakout room function was very useful for group work and I think it made it easy to ensure that everyone's voice was heard.
The seminar was really fun in relation to my other virtual classes.
I think the course did as well as could be expected considering the pandemic.

I did like how most of our classes did not involve screen-sharing, so that we could see each other's faces throughout discussion. This made discussions easier to follow. It also helped to have breakout rooms and use the whiteboard feature.
Full group discussion went well. I think Zoom white boards and breakout sessions were hit or miss. In the future, I think they should always have time for a recap after.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES. Take it!
Yes, Cara was truly the best professor for this class, as she is knowledgeable and creates an inviting class atmosphere.

I would absolutely recommend this course for anyone interested in global health or even public health in general. It's a really good way to be introduced to important topics in global health and ethics.

Yes, the material was exceptionally engaging and the course load is manageable but also rigorous. The Professor is very kind and actually puts an effort into developing meaningful relationships with her students.
Definitely. It develops an interesting way of looking at global health issues and a completely new perspective.
Yes, it is very interesting and useful not only for healthcare but to learn to analyze the ethical benefits and drawbacks of any setting.

Yes, the class was well-organized and the papers gave great insights and topics for discussion. Even paper assignments gave me the liberty to explore different global health topics and now I have a better understanding of how to use ethics as a tool

I think that this course is a necessary course for every global health scholar. It encouraged me to think more about contextual understandings and challenged the normative "right way" to do global health
Yes! The course material was interesting and general class format was genuinely fun.
Professor Fallon was a great teacher, and made the course engaging. I would wholeheartedly recommend this course.

Yes! For any student studying public health or medicine, then I would recommend this course. Even if students are not interested in health, there are still topics that are relevant, including the use of data and surveillance. This course is very important in understanding that there are important principles to consider to ensure that our actions, especially in times of global crisis, have positive and negative consequences for populations. These must be balanced to induce equitable responses and truly promote health.

On the whole, yes. Like with any discussion course, your milage will vary depending on the dynamics of those in discussion. If people come with an open mind and a willingness to listen, I find these types of courses are more successful. With regards to this class specifically, it makes for a good first ethics course (it was mine!) as Professor Fallon spends a week on the basics to give everyone a foundation and shared vocabulary to work off of. From there, we moved on to specific case studies and health-related ethical dilemmas. The dilemmas chosen were interesting and discussion drew heavily from the readings. The papers gave students a lot of freedom to choose dilemmas and topics of interest to them specifically.
